title: Episode 12: Personal Truth vs  Ultimate Truth
description: Today I process through the idea of personal truth and ultimate truth, exploring what those things mean in the frame of subjectivism and how they relate to each other.

transcript_parts.text: [Music]
welcome to another episode of the
information etics podcast my name is
cassidy
i'm an information addict and this is my
podcast where i explore information
ideas and beliefs and try to do those
things more responsibly
so today i've got a monologue video and
i know i've had a lot of conversations
lately
and i've really enjoyed those but i have
been feeling lately that i want to kind
of
take a step back and before i start
exploring more beliefs
and the way that we interact with them i
kind of want to go to the core
and sort of the roots of what i think
this
lies in and probably elude the the seeds
and the roots of
where all of this why all of this has
led me here
and that's sort of this idea of truth
and exploring that
so about five years ago before i started
my
deconstruction i had a conversation with
a friend and i don't quite remember what
it was about but
it was probably about religion or
something and i remember having the
conversation
and responding to some question about
how i personally found something to be
true
and they said something to me that sort
of stuck in my brain and then i could
never really
shake and it was that just because i
personally believe something to be true
doesn't mean make that ultimately true
and
in the grand scheme of things that's a
very simple
thing to say and sort of a simple idea
but it's
it got me to stop and to think and it
made me sort of
re-evaluate and think about the way that
i was processing things
and sort of why i was processing
information in the first place
i think there's a lot of reasons why we
can
seek out information i think one of the
big ways is because we want to be
better communicators in conversations we
want to be
informed we want to have the the right
information to be able to sit and talk
with others we care about whether it's
to really connect with them maybe even
impress them or just
not feel like you're being blindsided
and so
we chase those things to have that at
our disposal and ready to
be better communicators i think on the
other side there's this also
level of security that comes from
having information we we need something
solid to stand on we need a foundation
and we use information and the
cultivation of that to create that thing
that we can
look to and hold on to and gives us
something to hold on to as we move
forward and act in the world
and while both of those things are
can be good and bad and i've probably
participated in
information consumption on both levels
i think at the root of
what was driving me to consume was this
sense of seeking truth you know i wanted
to know
what was true and try to make sense of
the chaos
and the varying opinions that were out
in the world
and i use information and the
consumption of that
to help me try to evaluate and and get
to that
sort of perspective of truth and you
know as
we as humans start consuming information
and engaging with other people
and and living and experiencing life we
start
picking up these pieces of information
and putting them together
and creating a world view and
a set of beliefs that we individually
hold to be true
and for me this is sort of the process
and what you know entails this idea of
personal truth
it's the deep-held beliefs ideas
opinions um you know life experiences
that shape you and
give you a view of the world and how you
perceive it through
and often when you start talking about
personal truth
there's a tendency to lead into
subjectivism
now i
do not want this video to all to be
about subjectivism but i did want to
address it
a minute because it's so easy to take
this idea of personal truth and pivot to
that area so
before i kind of move on i just want to
tackle that
and walk through that so subjectivism
you know this idea that
uh there isn't really objective truth in
the world it's all sort of
personally curated what might be true
for me is not necessarily true for you
and that's very broad sort of broad
paintbrush
definition but when we talk about
subjectivism
in broader culture i think that's what
most people think about it
you know this opinion-based idea of what
is true
and because there's so many varying
beliefs and there's this spirit of
respecting other people
and their journeys and their convictions
in the broader culture it becomes really
easy to say it might be reasonable that
subjectivism is true and everything
that we see within our differences is
just
a accumulation of personal taste and so
we shouldn't be so worried about these
huge differences that we see in the
world and i'm not going to argue that
subjectivism doesn't exist to any extent
because i don't think that's true
and i don't think anyone really thinks
that's true i think there's a lot of
things that we can all agree on
that at the at the end of the day there
can be discrepancies
in what we believe and it doesn't matter
but i think the bigger question is
is everything that we believe subjective
is all
our world shaped by personal truth
and through the time that i've taken to
process all of this stuff i found that
world view
very unsustainable and there's a lot of
reasons but
to get to the the core of it i think the
biggest reason
i can't hold to subjectivism is because
i can't ever
act like i really believe it's true
anytime
i believe an action an idea or an
ideology is more
profitable than another enough to where
i'm willing to argue it
over another it kind of goes in the face
of the ideology of subjectivism it
doesn't doesn't align with that
worldview
and you could make the case that
the worldview still exists but i'm not
operating in the right spirit and
that's a distinct possibility but even
if i got to the place where
i could figure out how to live as
subjectivism really
is true and never never judge another
opinion
over another and act as if they're all
personal preferences
the ideology leaves me with a question
of why i should even believe that
ideology is better than another or just
my subjective taste
and i don't think there's a way we can
ever find
a way to agree and probably not a reason
to try to get everybody to agree
because what's the point i mean except
for maybe some
social harmony or you know having some
instinct within us that that that helps
our survival but
at the end of the day that doesn't give
me clarity about
the truth of those things either so it
feels like i'm left with nothing
to ground myself in i'm just surrounded
by a hot podge of
personal ideas that's been personally
curated for myself
with no real justification of why i
should believe something over another
and then outside of that i think when it
comes to subjectivism it leaves us to
question
what truth is at all and the place that
it holds within our world
if all truth is just created by a
personal whim
and there's no real universal
understanding of anything
that we can all agree on outside of our
own
personal preferences i don't see a way
to really
have truth so in this case to me truth
becomes a delusion
and there's nothing i can really or say
or do
to defend it i think if we're honest
with ourselves
none of us are full-blown wholesale
subjectivists
even though that may seem appealing
although i think you really
start thinking about it and take that to
its logical conclusion
there are some issues with this
subjectivism idea that
can be pretty troubling but again this
video is not really about subjectivism
this is about
personal truth and ultimate truth and
how we can
understand those things and how they
work in the way that we confront ideas
and information
so when we're talking about truth i
think it's safe to say that
it's something bigger than just what we
personally believe or we put our trust
in
there's something outside of that
we're never going to escape looking at
the world in a subjective manner because
that's
the only way we can we experience the
world individually
and we're processing it through our
emotions and our background
and our limited subjective opinion
but although we view the world through
our subjective lenses and our subjective
experience
is we do have certain personal beliefs
that are making objective truth claims
about the world we can't
we can't escape that and if there is
some objective reality
outside of our personal world then there
is something that is ultimately true
so if there is something that is
ultimately true
it would be all of the things that make
up our rejective reality
it's the facts the figures the data that
come together
to show us how the world actually is
what lies
in it and underneath it it's the
foundation
that we can stand on and we can point to
and get a bearing of what's
real outside of ourselves and it
wouldn't be shaped by our own opinions
and perspectives of personal truth in
fact it's
unfazed by it so if personal truth and
ultimate truth both exist
my next question is does it matter if
they line up does it matter that they're
congruent with each other
and i think the answer to that question
is it depends
so if subjectivism is true
my personal opinion doesn't really
matter but
if objectivism is true even to
a mild degree my personal beliefs and
actions
do have a potential to have an effect on
the way they interact with reality i
think the severity of
those discrepancies would probably
depend on the significance of
how those two things interact within the
world
and what are the consequences for my
false belief
matching with reality for example
let's take the earth question is it flat
is it round
i want to know the right answer i want
to hold the answer that's ultimately
true
but when i really think about the
consequences
that lie within my everyday life of
having the wrong answer that question
it's very limited
i'm still going to go on about my day
and there's not a lot to risk
however if i have the wrong assumptions
about gravity and i act off them
jumping off a cliff could be very
life-threatening and the risks are much
higher to having the wrong
answer personally to that question and
so
there are i think that we can show that
depending on what we're talking about
there are certain things that it's more
important to know the truth of than
others now this is where i think
religion spirituality and these
big cosmic conversations start to
complicate the
equation now there are some religions
and some world views
that have more of a universal view
a little more space and wiggle room for
the answers to all these questions and
there's some world views that i think
subjectivism fits in just
fine but on the other hand there's other
world views that are incredibly
exclusive
and to have them sit together side by
side
creates world views that are
diametrically opposed
and i don't think that's something we
should ignore i think there are some
things we can more easily demonstrate
and understanding the severity of
knowing the truth
of them and i think often when we're
talking about religion and what we
personally
believe to be true
it's hard to separate that from this
idea of ultimate truth and how do we
compare that with the other world views
and religions around us
and what is the severity of those things
being
true or untrue in some world views the
severity of those things being truthful
or not truthful are inconsequential
but in others they're not and depending
on which
worldview ends up being ultimately true
it comes with a lot of implications
and could potentially drastically affect
the way
that we should design and live our lives
the hard part about religion
is that it's so deeply ingrained in so
many people and i personally believe
that
human beings are very religious beings
and we can't help it
and i think it's really easy for us to
look at our own personal truth and try
to see the objective world we see
outside of ourselves
and fit it into our frames and instead
of
being willing to break our categories
and change those things
we can easily fall in the trap of making
those things
fit our world or rejecting the
information we don't like
so as i've continued to walk this path
and engage
ideas and really tackle the big
questions it given me a huge respect
for this idea of truth and not just on
the personal level but in the ultimate
sense
it's what's driven me to this path of
information consumption
but it's also driven me into more
engagement with
ideas and people and tackling the big
questions in a more open way
and i found that when i pursued these
things
with truth in the right place and in the
right spirit
it's helped me do these things better so
moving forward
especially in the next couple of videos
i'm going to keep unpacking this
relationship between personal truth
and ultimate truth and
i want to explore why both of them are
important
and how to engage better in the pursuit
of both of those things
but for now i will close with the
serenity prayer
god grant me this remedy to accept the
things i cannot change
the courage to change the things i can
and the wisdom to know the difference
